title: Is the function f(x) =x concave up, concave down, or does it have no concavity? - Quora

response.answer_text: Is the function f(x) =x concave up, concave down, or does it have no concavity? We don’t usually worry about this. Informally it is neither convex, nor concave from either direction. However we define a convex function to be one for which all points on a line segment joining two points on the graph lie on or above the graph. So a function with a straight line graph is convex. It is not strictly convex; strictly implies that the inequality is strict except at the end points of the line segment.

The function is both convex and concave, but it is neither strictly convex nor strictly concave. A second differentiable function is convex if f′′(x)≥0f″(x)≥0 everywhere, while it is strictly convex if f′′(x)>0f″(x)>0 everywhere.
Q: Is the function f(x) =x concave up, concave down, or does it have no concavity? I would say that it has no concavity.
